abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey an unsatisfactory project
            outcome, and negligible institutional development impacts;
            yet, sustainability is likely. In addition, both
            performances by the Bank and Borrower are rated
            unsatisfactory. Lessons address the following: 1) building
            effective regulation capacity is a long term endeavor. The
            objective was to make regulatory arrangements converge, in
            the medium term, into an independent, fully operational and
            multi-sectoral regulatory agency. However, progress made to
            date needs to be sustained, and in line with global best
            practices; and this effort requires an engagement beyond the
            project life; 2) focus on outcomes should be at the center
            of the dialogue with the client Government throughout
            project implementation, to ensure not only its commitment,
            but also that costly technical work is used; 3) Bank
            supervision efforts should be consistent throughout the
            project life, to ensure continued dialogue, and avoid delays
            in project implementation, and an increased number of Bank
            supervision missions should be attained, preferably with a
            strengthened presence, for continued follow up on mission
            conclusions. 4) effective communication with stakeholders is
            key to successful implementation of a privatization program,
            an effort which should be sustained, even amplified,
            throughout project implementation, so as to overcome the
            resistance of vested interests; and, 5) Co-financing is a
            risk factor requiring mitigation throughout implementation.
            Therefore, the Bank team should attempt to define realistic
            performance indicators, taking into account only the
            potential direct impact of the project in relation with the
            Bank funds.
